machine_learning_intro.title: Introduction to Machine Learning
machine_learning_intro.summary: Machine Learning (ML) is a subfield of AI focused on the use of algorithms that can learn patterns from data without being explicitly programmed. It encompasses supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning paradigms. Core methods include regression, classification, clustering, and model evaluation metrics. Understanding the trade-offs between bias and variance, overfitting, and model generalization is key for applying ML in production settings.

exploratory_data_analysis.title: Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)
exploratory_data_analysis.summary: EDA is the foundational step in any data science workflow. It involves summarizing datasets both visually and statistically to identify patterns, spot anomalies, test hypotheses, and check assumptions. Key tools include histograms, boxplots, pairplots, and correlation matrices. Advanced EDA extends to multivariate analysis, distributional assumptions, handling missing data patterns, and understanding feature interactions that may influence modeling decisions.

business_analytics_fundamentals.title: Business Analytics Fundamentals
business_analytics_fundamentals.summary: Business Analytics is the practice of using data to make strategic decisions and measure performance. Key concepts include tracking Key Performance Indicators (KPIs), customer acquisition costs, conversion funnels, and retention/churn metrics. Tools like SQL, Tableau, and Power BI are commonly used to explore business data and visualize insights. Modern analytics also integrates predictive models to guide decision-making under uncertainty.

deep_learning_vs_traditional_ml.title: Deep Learning vs Traditional ML
deep_learning_vs_traditional_ml.summary: Traditional ML methods like decision trees, logistic regression, and SVMs require manual feature engineering and work well on structured/tabular data. Deep Learning, on the other hand, automatically learns hierarchical representations from raw data using neural networks. While DL excels at tasks like image recognition and NLP, it is compute-intensive, requires large datasets, and is less interpretable. Choosing between them depends on data type, complexity, and resource availability.

generative_ai_overview.title: Generative AI Overview
generative_ai_overview.summary: Generative AI refers to models that can generate new content — text, images, code, or even music — based on learned patterns. Large Language Models (LLMs) like GPT and image generators like DALL·E use deep learning architectures (mostly transformers) trained on massive datasets. Applications span writing, design, education, and software development. Challenges include hallucinations, ethical concerns, and content control.
